author: Brandon Watson
title: Sturgis, Colon, Constantine and Mendon to open playoffs on the road
text: Sturgis, Colon, Constantine and Mendon to open playoffs on the road Prep football playoff pairings Posted Oct. 25, 2015 at 9:13 PM Four local football teams made the MHSAA football playoffs, which begin at the end of this week. Sturgis and Colon both automatically qualified during the regular season by picking up six wins. Both Mendon and Constantine waited until Sunday night to find that they had been selected as at-large 5-4 teams to make the post season. In a total of 40 teams with 5-4 records were taken by the MHSAAto play in the playoffs, completing the field to 256 schools. All four teams will open up on the road. Sturgis at St. Joseph Sturgis (6-3) qualified for the playoffs by winning its sixth game over Plainwell in Week 8. The Trojans last were in the playoffs in 2013, when they qualified as a 5-4 team, but they fell in the opening round on the road at St. Joseph, 16-0. The Trojans are the fourth seed in the district with 63.000 playoff points. The Bears went 8-1 overall this season and finished with 100.111 playoff points and the only loss f the season came against Stevensville-Lakeshore, 28-14 in Week 4. The Bears won the last five games of the season, averaging 39 points per game in those wins, though 59 came against Niles (2-7) in Week 7. Sturgis coachJimmy Lamb confirmed Sunday that the Trojans will travel west to play St. Joseph at 7 p.m. Friday night. The Trojans and Bears have met three times all-time, Sturgis has won two of those three meetings. Constantine at Schoolcraft Constantine (5-4) and Schoolcraft (9-0) know all about each other, having played 67 games prior to this one. TheFalcons own a 39-28 all-time advantage over Schoolcraft, the Eagles won this year’s game two weeks ago 42-24. Constantine finished at 5-4 with 51.889 playoff points, Schoolcraft had 89.778 points. The 24 points by Constantine against Schoolcraft were the second-most points scored on the Eagles this season. Watervliet scored the most at 33 points, but fell 34-33 to the Eagles back in the second week of the season. Schoolcraft enters the game ranked as theNo. 3 team in the APDivision 6 poll. The Eagles are averaging almost 41 points per game, Constantine is averaging 35 points on the button. The game will be played on Friday night at 7 p.m., Constantine coach Shawn Griffith confirmed on Sunday night. Mendon at Climax-Scotts Mendon and Climax-Scotts have grown accustomed to playing each other in the post season. The Hornets have had the upper hand as well, ending Climax-Scotts’ season in each of the last four playoffs as well as the 2005 and 2003 seasons. Mendon owns a 43-6-1 record all-time against Climax-Scotts as well. At just 5-4, Mendon got into the playoffs thanks to a four-game winning streak that saw them hold White Pigeon, Bronson, New Buffalo and Centreville to a combined 20 points. The Hornets fell 13-7 to Mount Pleasant Sacred Heart last week, but played a tough game and hurt themselves with four turnovers. Page 2 of 2 - This is the ninth straight seasonMendon has qualified for the playoffs. Mendon finished this season with 41.111 playoff points, Climax-Scotts had 67.000 The game will be played on Friday at 7 p.m., Mendon co-athletic director GlenSamson said on Sunday night. Colon at Pittsford Colon qualified for the playoffs on the last week of the season, beating White Pigeon 16-8. The playoff berth is the Magi’s second in a row, they dropped a 49-8 decision to Mendon last year in Division 8. Colon won each of the last three games, out-scoring NorthAdams-Jerome, Camden-Frontier and White Pigeon by a combined 124-40. “We’re ecstatic,”Colon coachRichard Roth said on Sunday night. Colon dropped a 27-8 game to Pittsford earlier this season, but Roth said his team has grown up and become more mature. Colon and Pittsford have met on 11 occurrences all-time, Pittsford owns a 7-4 record against them in those games. The Magi finished with 41.667 playoff points on the season, Pittsford had 41.778 points. The game will be played on Friday at 7 p.m., Roth confirmed on Sunday night.
